Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I was chatting with Mark, an acquaintance from the gym, during my shift as a lifeguard. We stood near the pool, keeping an eye on the swimmers. Mark leaned in and whispered, “Did you see how badly Sarah messed up the schedule last week? She’s always making mistakes.” I felt a twinge of discomfort—gossip wasn’t something I wanted to encourage, and I knew Sarah worked hard. At the same time, out of the corner of my eye, I noticed a group of teenagers laughing and preparing to dive right next to the big, bold “NO DIVING” sign. My job demanded I enforce the rules immediately, but Mark was waiting for my response, expecting me to join in or at least acknowledge his comment. I felt torn, caught between the urge to redirect Mark away from gossip and the responsibility to stop the teens before someone got hurt. My heart pounded as I weighed which role to prioritize, feeling the pressure of both expectations closing in on me.
